awd_titl_txt: RoL:FELS: A Summit on New Interdisciplinary Research Directions on the Rules of Life
awd_abstract_narration:
Biological systems are extremely diverse and complex, possessing enormous variation. Understanding the mechanisms by which biological systems work is one of the fundamental scientific challenges of our time. Rules of Life offer principles - which are broadly applicable across bacteria, plants, and animals - that can be the basis for organized research programs that address the challenge of understanding nature. Unlike a traditional workshop or conference, the format of the Summit is designed to build interdisciplinary connections through provocative talks, panel discussions, and focused break-out sessions. Additionally, talks on emerging technologies and methods will broaden the perspectives of participants who may not have prior exposure to these tools.  The two follow-up workshops will encourage participants to plan how connections made at the Summit can be long lasting and lead to concrete outcomes.

The Mathematical Biosciences Institute (MBI) will organize a Summit on the Rules of Life in June 2019. This project will support the development of a networked community of researchers seeking to better understand the fundamental mechanisms that govern biological systems.  This community will be convened at a Summit on the Rules of Life held at the Mathematical Biosciences Institute in Columbus, OH.  Prominent biological scientists from across the world, together with newer researchers and individuals with expertise in emerging technologies and mathematical/statistical methodologies, will jointly explore the common principles that govern biological systems.  Video of the plenary lectures, panel discussions, and emerging technologies/methods talks delivered at the Summit will be live streamed and archived on the MBI website for later viewing.  The Summit will lead to two shorter follow-up workshops on emerging themes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Biological systems are extremely diverse and complex, governed by homeostatic and adaptive mechanisms with enormous variation in the component parts. Understanding the mechanisms by which biological systems work is one of the fundamental scientific challenges of our time. Rules of Life offer principles ? which are broadly applicable across bacteria, plants, and animals ? that can be the basis for organized research programs that address this challenge.

In order to create a networked community of research using the Rules of Life to understand biological systems, this project began with a Summit on the Rules of Life at the Mathematical Biosciences Institute (MBI), located in Columbus, OH on the campus of The Ohio State University. The Summit brought together a diverse collection of researchers representing various biological communities and the mathematical sciences. Prominent scientists came together with newer researchers and individuals with expertise in emerging technologies and methodologies that provided valuable insight. The Summit was structured to emphasize discussion through provocative talks, panel discussions, and intimate break-out sessions. The Summit led to three smaller follow-up workshops focusing on issues that emerged: natural selection and dormancy, emergence of cell differentiation in early multicellular evolution, and approximate symmetries.

Invasion and Defense was a Rule of Life for the Summit. The first follow-up group proposed Dormancy as another Rule of Life, as it is a behavior observed in many types of organisms including viruses, bacteria, fungi, and mammals (hibernation).  The group then focused on the interplay between natural selection, pathological invasion, and host immune defense in the cases where pathogens exhibit long dormancy periods.  Their white paper on the origins and mechanisms of dormancy and the consequences for infection and control reviews key biological and mathematical issues and presents several open research questions.

Symmetry and Polarity was another Rule of Life for the Summit, with the evolution of multicellularity as a topic. The second follow-up group focused on the evolution of multicellular life as a pivotal transition enabling a dramatic increase in organism size and complexity and, crucially, requiring the emergence and evolution of multiple cell types. While previous studies have often addressed mechanisms that may underlie symmetry breaking in a previously homogeneous cell population, real comprehension of the dynamics and evolution of cellular differentiation also requires understanding in a precise way what makes one cell type different from others: a theoretical framework that also accommodates empirical advances as new technologies improve profiling of individual cells. In a peer-reviewed paper, the group discusses problems arising when interpreting data and model behaviors and shows how Boolean Networks can aid in placing empirical findings into a coherent conceptual framework.

The third follow-up group was also drawn to Symmetry and Polarity. They noted that, while virtually all forms of life - from single-cell eukaryotes to highly complex organisms - exhibit symmetry, the symmetry is often only approximate. Thus, precise measures of symmetry are often difficult to formulate and apply in a manner meaningful to biological systems, where symmetries and asymmetries can be dynamic and transient, or may be visually apparent but not reliably quantifiable using standard measures from mathematics and physics. In a peer-reviewed publication, the group presents and illustrates a novel measure that draws on concepts from information theory to quantify the degree of symmetry, enabling the identification of approximate symmetries that may be present in a pattern or a biological image.

All follow-up groups involved new collaborations among individuals at diverse career stages (graduate student to eminent professor). Both the original Summit speakers and the follow-up groups showed a high level of participation by women and individuals from underrepresented groups as well as diversity in the level of research activity at the home institution.

The results of the follow-up workshops are described in two white papers and two peer-reviewed journal articles, all posted at the website https://mbi.osu.edu/events/mbi-summit-rules-life
